div.ab:
ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ. ἐπὶ Πύρρου ἄρχοντος ἐν Δελφοῖς,
Ἀθήνησιν δὲ Διονυσίου τοῦ μετὰ Λυκίσκον,
οἵδε ἀπεστάλησαν θεωροὶ ὑπὸ τοῦ δήμου
τοῦ Ἀθηναίων, συμπέμψοντες τὴν Πυθα
ΐδα

Δημαίνετος Δημέου,
Εὔδημος Σαραπίωνος, γόνῳ Γοργίππου,
ανος Γοργίππου,
Χάρης Χάρητος νεώτερος,
Πτολεμαῖος Εὐβούλου,
Εὔβουλος Εὐβούλου, Διονύσιος Εὐβούλου,
Ῥαδάμανθυς Ἀττινοῦ,
Σώστρατος Ἀλεξάνδρου,
Ξένων Φιλάνθου,
Λυσίας Πύρρου.

θεωροὶ ἐκ Τετραπολέων·
Μητρόδωρος Καλλισστράτου,
Δαμόκριτος Δαμοκρίτου,
Ἡνιοχίδης Εὐφιλήτου.
ἐκ Πυρρακιδῶν·
Τιμάναξ Εὐκλέους Φλυεύς

div.p:
For Good Fortune. In the archonship of Pyrrhos at Delphi,+1+
and of Dionysios after Lykiskos in Athens,
these sacred delegates (theoroi) from the People
of Athens were dispatched to help in conducting the Pytha
is+2+.

Demainetos son of Demeas,
Eudemos son of Sarapion, by birth son of Gorgippos,+3+
anos son of Gorgippos,
Chares the younger, son of Chares,
Ptolemaios son of Euboulos,
Euboulos son of Euboulos, Dionysios son of Euboulos,
Rhadamanthys son of Attinos,
Sostratos son of Alexandros,
Xenon son of Philanthos,
Lysias son of Pyrrhos.

Sacred delegates (theoroi) from Tetrapolis:+4+
Mētrodōros son of Kallistratos,
Damokritos son of Damokritos,
Hēniochidēs son of Euphilētos
from Pyrrhakidai:+5+
Tiranax son of Euklēs of PhlyaXIII.

+1+ This text was inscribed on one block on the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury, below the list of theōroi for the first Pythaïs in 138/7 BCE. For more detail on Hellenistic inscriptions on the Athenian Treasury, see Note 1 for F.Delphes III 2.3; on the Pythais, see IG II3 4, 18 with notes.
Textual Note. After consulting the squeezes at Inscriptiones Graecae, the editor gives variant readings in comparison with F.Delphes III 2 and Tracy, BCH 99 (1975), 190: l. 1.2, a break should be mentioned; l. 2.1, the Π has three legs rather than two, probably due to a stonecutter's fault; 2.6, the last Υ is visible.!

+2+ The first five lines were inscribed with slightly larger letters and thicker serifs. The fifth line, having only three letters, serves as a visual break between the title parts (l. 1–4) and the name lists from l. 6 onwards.!
+3+ For the formula indicating the natural father, now see AIUK Papers 4.5, 59. This Eudemos reappeared in F.Delphes III 2.27, 2.14, where we know he belonged to Kekropis phylē.

+4+ Tetrapolis, a community in Attica including the cities of Marathon, Probalinthos, Trikorythos and Oinoi. For the community in detail, see SEG 50.168, note 1; The community maintained a special connection with Delphi independently from Athens, even when the Sanctuary of Apollo was under the dominance of Aitolians: Delphi honoured Tetrapolis because of their 'proximity with the god' and rendered them the privilege of perennial promanteia (the collective priority of consulting the oracle) and 'the right to sacrifice at the altars in the first place after the Delphians' (prothysia), see F.Delphes III 2.18 (mid-third century), 2.19 (Chronologie delphique K24, reengraved in the second century), 2.20 (the last one dated to 178/7 BCE) = Choix des inscriptiones de Delphes, No. 198–200.

Column 2 was inscribed right below Column 2 of F.Delphes III 2.7, where the theoroi also from Tetrapolis were added later than the original engraving. As the block still has much space below Column 1, it seems that the layout suggests a continuity of Tetrapolitan theoroi between the two Pythaïdes. See also Karila-Cohen in Baslez and Prévot, Prosopographie et histoire religieuse, 76–80; Humphreys, Kinship in Ancient Athens, 2019, 657.

+5+ Pyrrhakidai was a genos of Athens, perhaps emerging in the late second century BCE, though two inscriptions dated to ca.400 on Delos recorded two names as 'of Pyrrhakidai' (ID 66 and 67), suggesting an earlier affiliation to Delos. The name Timanax (also F.Delphes III 2.7 as patronym, perhaps the grandfather of Timanax here) was also attested more in the Cyclades than in Attica. See also Papazarkadas, Sacred and Public Land in Ancient Athens, 2012, Appendix V and Humphreys, Kinship in Ancient Athens, 2019, 680, 716.
